question: Q1. What is the main purpose of an HVAC system?
Q2. Which factor does NOT influence thermal wellbeing?
Q3. What type of heat transfer medium has high latent heat and requires special construction for condensate removal?
Q4. What is a major disadvantage of biomass boilers?
Q5. Which heat recovery technology involves two or more finned tube coils connected in a closed loop?
Q6. Which type of heat exchanger transfers both sensible and latent heat?
Q7. What is the purpose of a heat pump in an HVAC system?
Q8. What is the main drawback of using air-to-water heat pumps?
Q9. What is the ideal depth for installing a ground collector pipeline?
Q10. Which heat recovery method uses a revolving cylinder filled with air-permeable medium?
Q11. Why is oxygen-rich water harmful for heating systems?
Q12. What is the function of a district heating system?
Q13. What is the role of a recuperator in HVAC?
Q14. What happens if ethylene glycol leaks into domestic hot water?
Q15. What is the main operational principle of a heat pump?
Q16. What material should not be used for polymer pipelines in HVAC systems?
Q17. What type of heat exchanger is used in district heating systems?
Q18. What is the main benefit of using geothermal district heating?
Q19. How is frost protection typically achieved in solar thermal systems?
Q20. What is the ideal operating temperature range for water-to-water heat pump systems?
Q21. What is the main disadvantage of steam as a heat transfer medium?
Q22. What is the purpose of expansion vessels in HVAC systems?
Q23. What type of heat pump uses water extracted from wells as the heat source?
Q24. What does COP stand for in HVAC systems?
Q25. Which heat emitter provides the most even temperature distribution?
Q26. What is a key feature of district heating pipelines to handle thermal expansion?
Q27. What is the role of a mixing valve in coil loop heat recovery systems?
Q28. What is a common disadvantage of gas boilers?
Q29. What is the purpose of a rotary heat exchanger?
Q30. Why is glycol used in solar thermal systems for frost protection?
choices: To provide comfort and healthy environment
Requires more human effort for operation
To transfer heat from one medium to another
Temperature of the heat source varies significantly
It causes corrosion and damages metal parts
To recover energy from exhaust air
It is poisonous and dangerous to health
Absorbing heat at low temperature and releasing it at high temperature
Using propylene glycol, which is not poisonous
Using ethylene glycol, which is poisonous
Special construction required for condensate removal
To prevent overpressure in the system
To adjust the flow of working fluid
To store and transfer heat between air streams
It has a low freezing point and is non-toxic
hints: HVAC systems are designed to provide comfort and healthy indoor environments through heating, ventilation, and air conditioning.
Pipe material does not directly affect thermal wellbeing.
Steam has high latent heat, requiring special construction to handle condensation.
Biomass boilers require more manual handling and effort to operate.
Coil loops allow heat exchange between separate systems.
Rotary heat exchangers transfer both sensible and latent heat.
Heat pumps absorb and transfer heat between different mediums.
Air-to-water heat pumps' performance is affected by outdoor temperature changes.
Pipelines are usually installed at shallow depths for efficiency.
Rotary heat exchangers store heat in a rotating medium.
Oxygen causes corrosion and rusting in metal parts.
District heating systems distribute heat from a central source.
Recuperators recover heat from exhaust air to improve efficiency.
Ethylene glycol is poisonous; propylene glycol is used for safety.
Heat pumps operate based on the Carnot cycle.
Oxygen-diffusion resistant materials prevent corrosion.
Counter-flow plate heat exchangers are common in district heating.
Geothermal heating is independent from seasonal changes.
Propylene glycol prevents freezing without toxicity.
Water-to-water heat pumps work best in moderate temperature ranges.
Steam systems require special construction to manage condensation.
Expansion vessels prevent overpressure by absorbing excess volume.
Water-to-water heat pumps use groundwater as a heat source.
COP measures a heat pump's efficiency.
Surface heating systems provide the most even heat distribution.
U-bends compensate for expansion in district heating pipes.
Mixing valves regulate heat flow in coil loop systems.
Gas boilers have high installation costs.
Rotary heat exchangers store and transfer heat between airflows.
Glycol prevents freezing and ensures system safety.
